author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Divisions Harden in Senate as It Prepares to Receive Impeachment Article
description: Mitt Romney indicated that he believed the charge against former President Donald J. Trump was impeachable, while Marco Rubio called a trial “stupid.”
content: WASHINGTON — Lawmakers on Sunday burrowed into dueling positions over the impending impeachment trial of former President Donald J. Trump, deepening the schisms in an already divided Senate a day before the House will deliver its charge to lawmakers there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Cause of a Sleepless Night
description: Kevin Christian and Andrea Carla Michaels have a message for us.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — Timing is everything. And that is all I have to say about Kevin Christian and Andrea Carla Michaels’s crossword.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper
title: Some fans, including U.F.C. fighters, are being stymied by technical difficulties.
description: If you paid to watch tonight’s main event but cannot get ESPN+ to work, you’re not alone. Plenty of U.F.C. fighters are dealing with technical difficulties too:
content: If you paid to watch tonight’s main event but cannot get ESPN+ to work, you’re not alone. Plenty of U.F.C. fighters are dealing with technical difficulties too:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kristin Lin
title: America’s Other Front Line
description: As the Biden administration proposes additional pandemic relief, nonprofit workers see a country facing a growing crisis.
content: Kerri Lopez-Howell has spent the past year pivoting. Before the pandemic, her nonprofit, the Sunnyside Foundation, distributed education grants for the Sunnyside Unified School District in Tucson, Ariz. In March, it refocused its efforts to distribute relief funds to over 2,000 low-income families in the area, a coronavirus hot spot in the state. And in the weeks since the $900 billion stimulus package was signed into law, she’s turned her attention to the families that will still struggle to get federal relief.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Stenquist
title: Pay Less When You Drive Less
description: Is your car spending more time in the garage than on the road? You may be able to reduce your auto insurance payments.
content: Given the constraints of virus lockdowns and worries over health and safety, the bulk of your automobile use may be from grocery-store runs these days. Regardless of where you have gone in the past nine months, you’ve probably driven less than you did pre-pandemic, and that pattern could continue for many weeks or months to come. With reduced driving, you may be wondering if you can reduce your auto insurance payments. Here are some ways you can potentially save money. (But when reviewing insurance policies, always read the fine print. Some come with stipulations.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Cusumano
title: Find and Keep New Friends
description: The coronavirus pandemic has profoundly disrupted some social circles. Here’s what experts and new pals have to say about making, and maintaining, pandemic friends.
content: It took a pandemic, a layoff and last year’s racial-justice protests to impel Margo Gabriel, a travel and food writer, to finally fulfill a long-held aspiration: to move to Lisbon from Boston. “I was like, ‘OK, I really need to think about next steps,’” Ms. Gabriel, 34, said recently. “I’m getting older.” She applied for, and was accepted to, a two-year master’s program at the Universidade Católica Portuguesa. She arrived in October.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: The Upside of Surrendering No. 715
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, January 24, 2021.
content: “There was no book on Henry Aaron. He had the book on you. You pretty much went in there and said, ‘I hope my stuff is good enough tonight, because you’re going to need it.’”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlotte Cowles
title: The Week in Business: Biden Gets Down to Business
description: Biden started off his presidency with a flurry of economy-focused executive orders. Netflix’s budget broke even — for the first time. And Parler won’t be back online anytime soon.
content: All eyes are on President Biden right now. Here’s how his new policies will affect companies and households struggling to weather the pandemic economy — plus more of the week’s top business and tech news. Stay safe, everyone. — Charlotte Cowles
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Pietsch
title: Son Tipped Off F.B.I. About His Father, Who Is Charged in Capitol Riot
description: “I put my emotions behind me to do what I thought was right,” said Jackson Reffitt, who weeks before the siege alerted the F.B.I. that his father was planning “something big.”
content: Two days after the Capitol riot on Jan. 6, Jackson Reffitt’s father, Guy W. Reffitt, returned to the family’s home in Texas. He told his son that he had stormed the Capitol, according to an F.B.I. affidavit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Donald G. McNeil Jr
title: Fauci on What Working for Trump Was Really Like
description: From denialism to death threats, Dr. Anthony S. Fauci describes a fraught year as an adviser to President Donald J. Trump on the Covid-19 pandemic.
content: For almost 40 years, Dr. Anthony S. Fauci has held two jobs. As director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, he has run one of the country’s premier research institutions. But he has also been an adviser to seven presidents, from Ronald Reagan to, now, Joseph R. Biden Jr., called upon whenever a health crisis looms to brief the administration, address the World Health Organization, testify before Congress or meet with the news media.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Robbins
title: In Rural Montana, a Hope That Biden Will Reopen the Rails
description: The North Coast Hiawatha hasn’t run through Montana since 1979. Now cities like Billings, Bozeman, Helena and Missoula are hoping that “Amtrak Joe” will help fund new rail service.
content: DEER LODGE, Mont. — For nearly a century, passenger trains rumbled three times weekly through this broad, grass-rich mountain valley in central Montana, home to more cattle than people, until Amtrak pulled the plug on the North Coast Hiawatha in 1979.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Junior Mance, Jazz Pianist Who Played With Giants, Dies at 92
description: After working with Dizzy Gillespie and many others, he emerged as, in one critic’s words, “one of the most swinging and utterly delightful pianists in jazz.”
content: Junior Mance, a buoyant, bluesy jazz pianist who worked with some of the biggest names in jazz, including Lester Young, Dizzy Gillespie, Cannonball Adderley and Dinah Washington, before establishing himself as the leader of his own groups, died on Jan. 17 at his home in Manhattan. He was 92.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $650,000
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Hoffman
title: To Promote Vaccines, New Orleans Dances With Its Heart on Its Sleeve
description: The new, upbeat ‘Sleeves Up, NOLA’ campaign deftly uses local personalities and the Carnival dance culture to encourage citizens to get a Covid shot.
content: The snap of the snare drums is insistent. New Orleanians take joyous turns high-stepping and chicken strutting, dressed in the hand-sewn feathered finery of their social clubs and krewes. The celebration, shown on a new 30-second public service announcement airing in the city, is both resplendent and aching, an evocation of Carnival masking season that should have begun this month, culminating on Feb. 16 with Mardi Gras. All of it canceled, of course, by the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: The world approaches 100 million cases.
content: As the world approaches 100 million coronavirus cases — including 25 million in the U.S. as of Saturday — questions are surfacing about new variants of the virus that could slow or even reverse the progress that has been made toward ending the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Kurutz
title: When Dinner Is Outdoors, New Rules Apply
description: During the pandemic, wind chill and  loaner blankets are the new considerations (don’t forget your handwarmers).
content: When the weather turned cold, Rachel Sugar, a contributing writer for the New York City food blog Grubstreet, thought people would give up dining al fresco. But, she said, that hasn’t been the case: “Restaurants, more than ever, are a place where people feel relatively comfortable.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Benjamin Mueller
title: Britain’s Alarm Over Virus Variant Bolsters Case for Lockdown
description: A warning that the variant could be deadlier is a powerful argument that Britain could be entering a severe new phase of the pandemic and that easing lockdown rules could be calamitous.
content: LONDON — Britain’s disclosure Friday that a new variant of the virus could be deadlier than the original raised a stir about why such alarming information was put out when the evidence was so inconclusive. But there is little debate over its impact: It has silenced those who called for life to go back to normal any time soon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: Where Giuliani Still Routinely Offers False Claims of Election Fraud
description: A popular radio station in Manhattan has become a haven where conservative hosts like Rudolph Giuliani can defend Donald Trump.
content: His president and No. 1 client, Donald J. Trump, is no longer in office. His claims of election fraud, unfounded and disproved, were dismissed in courts across the country. He may still face criminal charges, and now there is a move to disbar him in New York.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gal Beckerman
title: Just Don’t Call Her a Ghostwriter
description: Michelle Burford has carved out a niche helping famous Black women like Cicely Tyson, Alicia Keys and Gabby Douglas write their memoirs. But she can tell many kinds of stories, including her own.
content: Michelle Burford has a fuzzy, purple ski hat, and when she puts it on, she can channel voices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Suhasini Raj
title: I Covered Coronavirus Victims. Then My Family Members Became Victims, Too.
description: Dealing with the pandemic on two fronts, as a journalist and as a wife and mother, taught me what empathy really means.
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jodi Archambault
title: How Covid-19 Threatens Native Languages
description: The average age of Lakota and Dakota speakers is 70. We are running out of time to save them.
content: CANNONBALL, N.D. — Over four centuries, nine out of 10 Native Americans perished from war or disease. Now our people are dying from Covid-19 at extraordinarily high rates across the country. North and South Dakota, home to the Lakota reservations, lead the United States for coronavirus rates per capita. We are losing more than friends and family members; we are losing the language spoken by our elders, the lifeblood of our people and the very essence of who we are.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Ramzy
title: Chinese Miners Pulled to Surface 2 Weeks After Underground Explosion
description: At least 11 miners who were trapped 2,000 feet below ground in the blast have been rescued. Others are still missing.
content: HONG KONG — Two weeks after an explosion left a group of miners trapped 2,000 feet below ground in the eastern Chinese province of Shandong, at least 11 were found alive and lifted to the surface on Sunday, a bright spot after a grueling and uncertain rescue effort.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Jeremiah M. Bogert, Jr
title: Impeachment, Coronavirus Vaccines, N.F.L. Playoffs: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: As Protests Shake Russia, Kremlin Drops Its ‘Navalny Who?’ Tack
description: A stark shift by the government shows its uncertainty as Aleksei A. Navalny’s dramatic return gives disgruntled Russians a clear leader to rally around.
content: MOSCOW — For years, the Kremlin tried to ignore the opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny, right down to avoiding the very mention of his name.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave
title: Asia’s ‘El Chapo’ Is Arrested in Amsterdam
description: Tse Chi Lop, said to be the leader of a multibillion-dollar drug syndicate, was arrested in Amsterdam and faces extradition to Australia.
content: SYDNEY, Australia — Tse Chi Lop is often compared to Mexico’s most famous drug lords for his alleged ability to move billions of dollars’ worth of methamphetamine into countries across Asia while living discreetly and avoiding law enforcement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Savor Soup Made From Scratch
description: With this foundation of vegetables and water, delicious, homemade soup doesn’t have to be complicated. Adding personality is up to you.
content: If a pot of homemade soup brings to mind a big kettle of many ingredients simmering for hours, think again. There’s an easy formula for preparing vegetable soups that requires only a few ingredients and minimal cooking time, yet yields the same rich comfort that soup is intended to provide. You need about a pound of fresh vegetables, three cups of water and a blender or a food processor (though a potato masher can be pressed into service). The result will be two generous portions of velvety warmth or four more modest servings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yanzhong Huang
title: Has China Done Too Well Against Covid-19?
description: The country doesn’t care enough about vaccination because of a false sense of security.
content: Jan. 23 was the anniversary of the lockdown in Wuhan, the first coronavirus lockdown anywhere in the world, and ahead of the occasion, the Chinese government ramped up efforts to showcase its triumph over that initial deadly outbreak.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Stein
title: He Bonded With Kobe as a Competitor, Then as Another #GirlDad
description: A year after Kobe Bryant’s fatal crash, the former N.B.A. All-Star Zach Randolph and his daughter MacKenly, who played for Bryant’s girls’ basketball team, are still learning how to grieve.
content: Zach Randolph and Kobe Bryant were contemporaries in the N.B.A.’s Western Conference for more than a decade. They were teammates in two All-Star Games. They even shared a workplace during Randolph’s brief stint with the Los Angeles Clippers, who played in the considerable Staples Center shadow of Bryant’s Los Angeles Lakers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Jan. 25, 2021
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘One Day, After Several Months of Not Stopping By, He Poked His Head In’
description: A man in search of a certain item, a bike bound for the trash heap and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sergey Ponomarev and Anton Troianovski
title: Pro-Navalny Protest Photos: Wave of Anger Rolls Across Russia
description: Demonstrators in more than 100 cities rallied in support of the jailed opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny in the biggest protests the nation has seen in years.
content: MOSCOW — Russians rallied in support of the jailed opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny in more than 100 cities on Saturday, the biggest protests in the nation since at least 2017.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: French Roosters Now Crow With the Law Behind Them
description: After a series of high-profile disputes in rural areas, the French Parliament has passed a bill that enshrines countryside smells and sounds as protected national heritage.
content: PARIS — The crow of a rooster and the ringing of a church bell at dawn. The rumble of a tractor and the smell of manure wafting from a nearby stable. The deafening song of cicadas or the discordant croaking of frogs. Quacking ducks, bleating sheep and braying donkeys.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Jan. 24, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Jan. 24, 2021.
content: An article on Page 4 about the actress Hunter Shafer misstates her age. She is 22, not 21.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: Yankees Bolster Rotation With Trade for Jameson Taillon
description: The right-hander, who missed 2020 after Tommy John surgery, joins a boom-or-bust rotation of pitchers working their way back.
content: The Yankees bolstered their 2021 rotation on Sunday by acquiring Jameson Taillon, a right-handed starter working his way back from elbow surgery, in a trade with the Pittsburgh Pirates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Ramzy
title: China Sends Warplanes to Taiwan Strait in a Show of Force to Biden
description: The exercises, which included 13 warplanes on Saturday and 15 on Sunday, were the biggest so far this year and the first under the new U.S. administration.
content: HONG KONG — China sent warplanes into the Taiwan Strait over the weekend, a show of force to the Biden administration that signals Beijing’s plans to maintain pressure on Taiwan even as it calls for a reset with the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Tour a Historic Home, From the Comfort of Your Own
description: Bored with your surroundings? Walk the (virtual) halls of some storied grand houses.
content: Have you ever had the dream where you take a test that you haven’t studied for? Or the one where you’re caught in a public place in your underwear? Here’s another common one: You open a door in your home and discover a room you have never seen before. To make this one a reality, just charge your laptop.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica L. Green
title: Surge of Student Suicides Pushes Las Vegas Schools to Reopen
description: Firmly linking teen suicides to school closings is difficult, but rising mental health emergencies and suicide rates point to the toll the pandemic lockdown is taking.
content: The reminders of pandemic-driven suffering among students in Clark County, Nev., have come in droves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Cusumano and Emma Grillo
title: Learn About Lichen and Sculpt a Self-Portrait
description: This week, celebrate Australia Day, make masala chai and listen to Natalie Portman discuss her new children’s book.
content: Here is a sampling of the week’s events and how to tune in (all times are Eastern). Note that events are subject to change after publication.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Hong Kong Crackdown Is an Early Test for Biden
description: Even with Trump out of office, prospects seem dim for rapprochement between China and the United States.
content: If the Biden administration was aiming to improve relations with China, events in the past few weeks have shown the depth of the chasm that has grown between Washington and Beijing in recent years on the most fundamental matters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: The Craziest Two Weeks of Tennis Practice Ever
description: The organizers of the Australian Open promised local residents that the tournament would not set off a coronavirus outbreak. Making good on that promise is very complex.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — The intricate ballet begins at sunrise and ends after dark, a complicated series of movements requiring the utmost precision for what has long been a very simple task — getting tennis players to and from the courts so they can practice ahead of a professional tournament.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: Ted Thompson, Who Helped Revive the Packers, Is Dead at 68
description: As Green Bay’s general manager, he made the decision — contentious at the time but later consequential — to draft Aaron Rodgers in the first round.
content: Ted Thompson, who as a longtime executive of the Green Bay Packers helped revive one of football’s most enduring dynasties, died on Wednesday at his home in Atlanta, Texas. He was 68.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Man Threatened to Assassinate Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, Officials Say
description: Garret Miller, who was among those who stormed the Capitol, also threatened the officer who fatally shot a Trump supporter, saying he would “hug his neck with a nice rope,” prosecutors said.
content: A Trump supporter who stormed the Capitol on Jan. 6 threatened on social media to assassinate Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez that day and also threatened the Capitol Police officer who fatally shot a woman as she tried to enter the Speaker’s Lobby, federal prosecutors said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Claire Saffitz has a new guide on making bagels that’s sure to demystify the process.
content: Good morning. I love a good bagel debate, love arguing chewiness, size, the slickness of a crust. I love someone explaining the logic behind a cinnamon raisin bagel with cream cheese and lox, discussing the merits of toasting or not toasting, making a passionate case for flagels, asking, “New York or Montreal?” (I grew up with New York bagels, watched them grow slack and airy and over-large. Now, I prefer what you get in Montreal.) Bagel consideration is important work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kirk Semple and Lena Mucha
title: For Nicaragua’s Lobstermen, Deadly Dives Are All Too Common
description: Catching spiny lobsters is a stunningly dangerous pursuit for the mostly Indigenous fishermen along the country’s Caribbean coast, requiring deep plunges with subpar gear.
content: PUERTO CABEZAS, Nicaragua — Every time he is out at sea, the lobster diver says a prayer just before he drops into the water in what has become a steadfast ritual since he nearly lost his life on a hunt three years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: George Armstrong, Who Led Toronto to 4 Stanley Cup Titles, Dies at 90
description: A 7-time All-Star and the longtime captain of the Maple Leafs, he was the first player of Indigenous descent to score in the N.H.L.
content: George Armstrong, the Hockey Hall of Fame forward and captain of the Toronto Maple Leafs teams that won four Stanley Cup championships in the 1960s, died on Sunday. He was 90.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner and Catie Edmondson
title: Pennsylvania Lawmaker Played Key Role in Trump’s Plot to Oust Acting Attorney General
description: The congressman’s involvement underlined how far the former president was willing to go to overturn the election, and Democratic lawmakers have begun calling for investigations into those efforts.
content: WASHINGTON — When Representative Scott Perry joined his colleagues in a monthslong campaign to undermine the results of the presidential election, promoting “Stop the Steal” events and supporting an attempt to overturn millions of legally cast votes, he often took a back seat to higher-profile loyalists in President Donald J. Trump’s orbit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper
title: Hall of Fame Voting, Once an Honor, Is Now Seen as a Hassle
description: Some writers are opting out of voting at all, saying the Baseball Hall of Fame is making them do the unsavory work of passing judgment on the steroid era.
content: When Jim Baumbach arrived in Cooperstown, N.Y., in the summer of 2007 to cover the inductions of Tony Gwynn and Cal Ripken Jr. into the Baseball Hall of Fame, the inescapable topic of the day was Barry Bonds, who was soon to become baseball’s career home run leader.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christy Harmon
title: Your Fingers Go In and They Can’t Get Out, Homemade Version
description: Weave a classic gag from newspaper, then find someone to fool.
content: If you’re not familiar with a finger trap, it’s traditionally a tube woven from bamboo that “traps” the fingers of an unsuspecting person who places them inside. While the origins of the finger trap are debatable, the simplicity and joy of one never gets old.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac
title: Uber, After Buying Postmates, Lays Off More Than 180 Employees
description: The layoffs include most of the executive team at Postmates, the food delivery app that Uber bought last year.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Uber on Thursday laid off roughly 185 people from its Postmates division, or about 15 percent of Postmates’ total work force, said three people with knowledge of the actions, as the ride-hailing giant consolidates its food delivery operations to weather the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Welcome to the Graveyard of New Year’s Resolutions
description: It seems a long time since we pledged to drink less, eat better, exercise more, cut spending and stop doom-scrolling. Be gentle on yourself: It’s been a tough month.
content: Dry January in 2021 was supposed to usher in a healthier new year and bid farewell to a horrible 2020 — and the drinking that came with it for many of us.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexander Burns
title: How Democrats Planned for Doomsday
description: A huge coalition of activist groups had been working together since the spring to make sure that Joe Biden won and that the “election stayed won” amid Donald Trump’s subterfuge.
content: The video call was announced on short notice, but more than 900 people quickly joined: a coalition of union officials and racial justice organizers, civil rights lawyers and campaign strategists, pulled together in a matter of hours after the Jan. 6 attack on Capitol Hill.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Sunday Read: ‘The Amateur Cloud Society That (Sort Of) Rattled the Scientific Community’
description: The improbable tale of how a British maverick harnessed crowdsourced meteorological discoveries to reveal the poetic wonders of the sky.
content: The cultural history of clouds seemed to be shaped by amateurs — the likes of Luke Howard and the Honorable Ralph Abercromby — each of whom projected the ethos of his particular era onto those billowing blank slates in the troposphere. Gavin Pretor-Pinney was our era’s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: How Tom Brady and the Buccaneers beat the Packers for a Super Bowl berth.
description: Brady will start in his 10th Super Bowl, and the Buccaneers will become the first team to play for the championship in its home stadium.
content: In March, seeking a rewarding second chapter to a glittering career, Tom Brady signed a $50 million free-agent contract with the Tampa Bay Buccaneers after 20 seasons and six Super Bowl victories as quarterback for the New England Patriots. The hope in Tampa was that Brady’s megawatt celebrity and proven talent could sprinkle a little stardust on a middling N.F.L. franchise and perhaps vault it to the league’s upper echelon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nellie Bowles
title: How to Keep Internet Trolls Out of Remote Workplaces
description: When companies move all employee communications online, they face the same problems as the rest of the internet. But they don’t have to let bad behavior seep in.
content: Gustavo Razzetti, who gets hired by companies to improve their work cultures, has noticed a change since the pandemic began last year: more political brawls, more managers losing control of their employees, a curious mix of hyper-engagement and lack of empathy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrin Bennhold and Michael Schwirtz
title: Capitol Riot Puts Spotlight on ‘Apocalyptically Minded’ Global Far Right
description: Leaderless but united by racist ideology that has been supercharged by social media, extremists have built a web of real and online connections that worry officials.
content: BERLIN — When insurrectionists stormed the Capitol in Washington this month, far-right extremists across the Atlantic cheered. Jürgen Elsässer, the editor of Germany’s most prominent far-right magazine, was watching live from his couch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Conlen, Denise Lu and James Glanz
title: Why Vaccines Alone Will Not End the Pandemic
description: New estimates suggest the vaccine rollout is no match for the severity of the U.S. outbreak, and stricter social distancing measures are needed to reduce infections.
content: New estimates suggest the vaccine rollout is no match for the severity of the U.S. outbreak, and stricter social distancing measures are needed to reduce infections.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Who Is to Blame for the American Diet?
description: Readers fault conventional nutrition advice and a lack of education in addition to Big Food.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Paths to Citizenship
description: Readers differ about what President Biden should do. Also: Donald Trump’s appeal to some Christians.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
